children.label: chap:3_Kinematics1D

children.value: In this chapter, we will introduce the tools required to describe motion in one dimension. In later chapters, we will use the theories of physics to model the motion of objects, but first, we need to make sure that we have the tools to describe the motion. We generally use the word “kinematics” to label the tools for describing motion (e.g. speed, acceleration, position, etc), whereas we refer to “dynamics” when we use the laws of physics to predict motion (e.g. what motion will occur if a force is applied to an object).

The most simple type of motion to describe is that of a particle that is constrained to move along a straight line (one-dimensional motion); much like a train along a straight piece of track. When we say that we want to describe the motion of the particle (or train), what we mean is that we want to be able to say where it is at what time. Formally, we want to know the particle’s
position as a function of time

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)

children.value: . The function will only be meaningful if:

children.html: xxx

children.value: -axis and the direction that corresponds to increasing values of

children.html: xxx
x=0x=0x=0

children.value: we specify the units for the quantity,

children.html: xxx

children.value: That is, unless all of these are specified, you would have a hard time describing the motion of an object to one of your friends over the phone.
In order to describe the motion of the grey ball along a straight line, we introduce the x-axis, represented by an arrow to indicate the direction of increasing

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: x=\̲S̲I̲{0.5}{m}

children.value: where we would like to describe the motion of the grey ball as it moves along a straight line. In order to quantify where the ball is, we introduce the “

Note that we are completely free to choose both the direction of the

children.html: xxx

children.value: -axis and the location of the origin. The

children.html: xxx

children.value: -axis is a mathematical construct that we introduce in order to describe the physical world; we could just as easily have chosen for it to point in the opposite direction with a different origin. Since we are completely free to choose where we define the

children.html: xxx

children.value: -axis, we should choose the option that is most convenient to us.
Now suppose that the ball in Figure
is rolling, and that we recorded its x position every second in a table and obtained the values in Table
(we will ignore measurement uncertainties and pretend that the values are exact).
Position of a ball along the x-axis recorded every second.

The easiest way to visualize the values in the table is to plot them on a graph. Plotting position as a function of time is one of the most common graphs to make in physics, since it is often a complete description of the motion of an object. We can easily plot these values in Python:

children.html: xxx

children.value: position of the ball increases linearly with time (i.e. it is a straight line). This means that in equal time increments, the ball will cover equal distances. Note that we also had the liberty to choose when we define

children.html: t=0t=0t=0

is linear, we can summarize our description of the motion using a function,

children.value: , instead of having to tabulate the values as we did in Table
. The function will have the functional form:

Positions as a function of time for two objects.

Until now, we have considered motion where the velocity is a constant (i.e. where velocity does not change with time). Suppose that we wish to describe the position of a falling object that we released from rest at time

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: t=\̲S̲I̲{0}{s}

children.value: . The object will start with a velocity of

as it falls. We say that an object is “accelerating” if its velocity is not constant. As we will see in later chapters, objects that fall near the surface of the Earth experience a constant acceleration (their velocity changes at a constant rate).

Formally, we define acceleration as the rate of change of velocity. Recall that velocity is the rate of change of position, so acceleration is to velocity what velocity is to position. In particular, we saw that if the velocity,

children.html: vxv_xvx​

children.value: , is constant, then position as a function of time is given by:

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \ref at position 39: …_0 + v_xt \tag{\̲r̲e̲f̲{eqn:chap3:1dxv…

children.value: Acceleration thus has dimensions of length over time squared, with corresponding S.I. units of m/s
(meters per second squared or meters per second per second).
Now that we have an understanding of acceleration, how do we describe the position of an object that is accelerating? We cannot use equation
, since it is only correct if the velocity is constant.

children.html: v(t=(N−1)Δt)=ax(N−1)Δt(at beginning of interval N)v(t=NΔt)=axNΔt(at end of interval N)vNavg=12ax(2N−1)Δt(average during interval)x(t=NΔt)=12ax(NΔt)2(position at end of interval)\begin{align*} v(t=(N-1)\Delta t) &= a_x (N-1) \Delta t &\text{(at beginning of interval N)}\\ v(t=N\Delta t) &= a_x N \Delta t &\text{(at end of interval N)}\\ v_N^{avg}&=\frac{1}{2}a_x(2N-1)\Delta t&\text{(average during interval)}\\ x(t=N\Delta t)&=\frac{1}{2}a_x(N\Delta t)^2&\text{(position at end of interval)} \end{align*}v(t=(N−1)Δt)v(t=NΔt)vNavg​x(t=NΔt)​=ax​(N−1)Δt=ax​NΔt=21​ax​(2N−1)Δt=21​ax​(NΔt)2​(at beginning of interval N)(at end of interval N)(average during interval)(position at end of interval)​

Position and speed as a function of time for the ball in example
We can divide the motion into three parts (shown by the vertical dashed lines in Figure

due to the constant negative acceleration from gravity. At

children.value: and the ball is momentarily at rest (as it reaches the top of the trajectory before falling back down).

children.value: , the velocity continues to decrease linearly (it becomes more and more negative) as the ball start to fall back down faster and faster. The position also starts decreasing just after

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: t=\̲S̲I̲{1,02}{s}

children.value: , as the ball returns back down to the point of release. At

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: t=\̲S̲I̲{2.04}{s}

children.value: , the ball returns to the point from which it was thrown, and the ball is going with the same velocity (
) as when it was released, but in the opposite direction (downwards).

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: t=\̲S̲I̲{2.04}{s}

children.value: If nothing is there to stop the ball, it continues to move downwards with ever increasing velocity. The position continues to become more negative and the velocity continues to become larger in magnitude and more negative.

In the previous example, our language was not quite as precise as it should be when conducting science. Specifically, we need a way to distinguish the situation when the velocity is decreasing (becoming more negative), while the object is actually going faster and faster (after

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: t=\̲S̲I̲{1.02}{s}

children.value: to refer to how fast an object is moving (how much distance it covers per unit time), and we will use the term
to also indicate the direction of the motion. In other words, the speed is the absolute value of the velocity
This is true for one-dimensional motion, whereas in two or more dimensions, velocity is a vector and speed is the magnitude of that vector.
. The speed is thus always positive, whereas the velocity can also be negative.
With this vocabulary, the speed of the ball in Figure

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: t=\̲S̲I̲{0}{s}
Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: t=\̲S̲I̲{1.02}{s}

children.value: , and increases thereafter. On the other hand, the velocity continuously decreases (it is always becoming more and more negative). Velocity is thus the more general term since it tells us both the speed and the direction of the motion.

Most objects do not have a constant velocity or acceleration. We thus need to extend our description of the position and velocity of an object to a more general case. This can be done in much the same way as we introduced accelerated motion; namely by pretending that during a very small interval in time,

children.html: Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: , the velocity and acceleration are constant, and then considering the motion as the sum over many small intervals. In the limit that

children.html: Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: tends to zero, this will be an accurate description.
Suppose that an object is moving with a non constant velocity, and covers a distance

children.value: Leibniz and Newton were the first to develop mathematical tools to deal with calculations that involve quantities that tend to zero, as we have here for our time interval

children.html: Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: . Nowadays, we call that field of mathematics “calculus”, and we will make use of it here. Using the vocabulary of calculus, rather than saying that “instantaneous velocity is the slope of the graph of position versus time at some point in time”, we say that “instantaneous velocity is the time derivative of position as a function of time”. We also use a slightly different notation so that we do not have to write the limit

children.html: lim⁡Δt→0\lim_{\Delta t\to 0}limΔt→0​

children.value: . The change in position is then given by:

\begin{align*}
\Delta x &= x(t_2) - x(t_1)\\
&=\left(x_0+v_{0x}t_2+\frac{1}{2}a_xt_2^2\right )- \left(x_0+v_{0x}t_1+\frac{1}{2}a_xt_1^2\right )\\
&=v_{0x}(t_2-t_1)+\frac{1}{2}a_x(t_2^2-t_1^2)\\
&=v_{0x}\Delta t+\frac{1}{2}a_x(t_2-t_1)(t_2+t_1)\\
&=v_{0x}\Delta t+\frac{1}{2}a_x\Delta t (t_2+t_1)\\
\end{align*}
children.html: Δx=x(t2)−x(t1)=(x0+v0xt2+12axt22)−(x0+v0xt1+12axt12)=v0x(t2−t1)+12ax(t22−t12)=v0xΔt+12ax(t2−t1)(t2+t1)=v0xΔt+12axΔt(t2+t1)\begin{align*} \Delta x &= x(t_2) - x(t_1)\\ &=\left(x_0+v_{0x}t_2+\frac{1}{2}a_xt_2^2\right )- \left(x_0+v_{0x}t_1+\frac{1}{2}a_xt_1^2\right )\\ &=v_{0x}(t_2-t_1)+\frac{1}{2}a_x(t_2^2-t_1^2)\\ &=v_{0x}\Delta t+\frac{1}{2}a_x(t_2-t_1)(t_2+t_1)\\ &=v_{0x}\Delta t+\frac{1}{2}a_x\Delta t (t_2+t_1)\\ \end{align*}Δx​=x(t2​)−x(t1​)=(x0​+v0x​t2​+21​ax​t22​)−(x0​+v0x​t1​+21​ax​t12​)=v0x​(t2​−t1​)+21​ax​(t22​−t12​)=v0x​Δt+21​ax​(t2​−t1​)(t2​+t1​)=v0x​Δt+21​ax​Δt(t2​+t1​)​

children.value: Using calculus to obtain position from acceleration

children.label: Using calculus to obtain position from acceleration

children.value: Now that we saw that we can use derivatives to determine acceleration from position, we will see how to do the reverse and use acceleration to determine position. Let us suppose that we have a constant acceleration,

children.html: ax(t)=axa_x(t)=a_xax​(t)=ax​

children.value: , and that we know that at time

The anti-derivative of a function is thus related to the area between the function and the horizontal axis. If we specify limits on the horizontal axis between which we calculate the area, then the anti-derivative is called an
. For example, if we wish to calculate the sum of

children.value: is a linear function when acceleration is constant, we can easily calculate the area between the curve and the horizontal axis. In the case of a linear function,

children.html: ∫tatbv(t)dt=base×average height=(tb−ta)×12(v(ta)+v(tb))=(tb−ta)12(v0x+axta+v0x+axtb)=(12(v0xtb+axtatb+v0xtb+axtb2))−(12(v0xta+axta2+v0xta+axtbta))=(v0xtb+12axtb2)−(v0xta+12axta2)\begin{align*} \int_{t_a}^{t_b}v(t) dt &= \text{base}\times\text{average height}\\ &=(t_b-t_a)\times\frac{1}{2}\left(v(t_a)+v(t_b)\right)\\ &=(t_b-t_a)\frac{1}{2}(v_{0x}+a_xt_a+v_{0x}+a_xt_b)\\ &=\left( \frac{1}{2}(v_{0x}t_b+a_xt_at_b+v_{0x}t_b+a_xt_b^2) \right)- \left( \frac{1}{2}(v_{0x}t_a+a_xt_a^2+v_{0x}t_a+a_xt_bt_a) \right)\\ &=\left( v_{0x}t_b+\frac{1}{2}a_xt_b^2 \right)-\left( v_{0x}t_a+\frac{1}{2}a_xt_a^2 \right) \end{align*}∫ta​tb​​v(t)dt​=base×average height=(tb​−ta​)×21​(v(ta​)+v(tb​))=(tb​−ta​)21​(v0x​+ax​ta​+v0x​+ax​tb​)=(21​(v0x​tb​+ax​ta​tb​+v0x​tb​+ax​tb2​))−(21​(v0x​ta​+ax​ta2​+v0x​ta​+ax​tb​ta​))=(v0x​tb​+21​ax​tb2​)−(v0x​ta​+21​ax​ta2​)​

. As you will see in your calculus course, the function

children.html: CCC

children.value: In order to describe the motion of an object confined to a straight line, we introduced a an axis (

children.html: xxx
xxx
x=0x=0x=0

children.value: ). Sometimes, it can be more convenient to use an axis that is
. For example, consider a person, Alice, moving inside of a train headed for the French town of Nice. The train is moving with a constant speed,

children.html: v′Bv'^Bv′B

children.value: as measured from the ground. Suppose that another person, Brice, describes Alice’s position using the function

children.html: xA(t)x^A(t)xA(t)

children.value: using an x-axis defined inside of the train car (

children.html: x=0x=0x=0

children.value: where Brice is sitting, and positive

children.html: xxx

children.value: is in the direction of the train’s motion), as depicted in Figure

below. As long as any person is in the train with Brice, they will easily be able to describe Alice’s motion using the x-axis that is moving with the train. Suppose that the train goes through the French town of Hossegor, where a surfer, Igor, watches the train go by. If Igor wishes to describe Alice’s motion, it is easier for him to use a different axis, say

children.html: x′x'x′

children.value: , that is fixed to the ground and not moving with the train.
Alice is walking in the train and her position is described by both Brice, who is sitting in the train (using the

children.html: xxx

children.value: axis), and Igor, who is at rest on the ground (using the

children.html: x′x'x′

children.value: Since Brice already went through the work of determining the function

children.html: xA(t)x^A(t)xA(t)

children.value: of the train, we wish to determine how to

children.html: xA(t)x^A(t)xA(t)

children.value: into the reference frame of the train station,

children.value: , so that Igor can also describe Alice’s motion. In other words, we wish to describe Alice’s motion in two different
A reference frame is simply a choice of coordinates, in this case, a choice of x-axis. Ideally, in physics, we prefer to use
reference frames, which are reference frames that are either “at rest” or that are moving at a constant speed relative to a frame that we consider at rest.

In principle, if you blocked out all of the windows in the train, it would not be possible for Alice and Brice to determine if the train is moving at constant speed or if it is stopped. Thus, the concept of a “rest frame” is itself arbitrary. It is not possible to define a frame of reference that is truly at rest. Even Igor’s frame of reference, the train station, is on the planet Earth, which is moving around the Sun with a speed of

Not only is it impossible to define a frame of reference that is truly at rest, the rules from transforming from one frame to the other depend on the speed between the reference frames. Our common experience is described by what we call “Galilean Relativity”, but if the speed between trains is very large, close to the speed of light, then we need to use Einstein’s Special Theory of Relativity.
, we wish to use Brice’s description of Alice’s motion,

children.value: Now that Igor can describe the position of the origin of Brice’s coordinate system, he can use Brice’s description of Alice’s motion. Recall that

children.html: xA(t)x^A(t)xA(t)

children.value: is Brice’s measure of Alice’s distance from his origin. Similarly,

children.html: x′B(t)x'^B(t)x′B(t)

children.value: , is Igor’s measure of the distance from his origin to Brice’s origin. Thus, to obtain Alice’s distance from Igor’s origin, we simply add the distance,

children.html: x′B(t)x'^B(t)x′B(t)

children.value: , from Igor’s origin to Brice’s origin, and then add,

children.html: xA(t)x^A(t)xA(t)

children.value: , the distance from Brice’s origin to Alice. Thus:

children.value: Since we know the position of Alice as measured in Igor’s frame of reference, we can now easily find her velocity and her acceleration, as measured by Igor. Her velocity as measured by Igor,

children.html: v′Av'^Av′A

children.value: , is given by the time-derivative of her position measured in Igor’s frame of reference:

children.html: v′A(t)=ddtx′A(t)=ddt(v′Bt+xA(t))=v′B+ddtxA(t)=v′B+vA(t)\begin{align} v'^A(t)&=\frac{d}{dt}x'^A(t)\\ &=\frac{d}{dt}(v'^Bt+x^A(t))\\ &=v'^B+\frac{d}{dt}x^A(t)\\ &=v'^B+v^A(t) \end{align}v′A(t)​=dtd​x′A(t)=dtd​(v′Bt+xA(t))=v′B+dtd​xA(t)=v′B+vA(t)​​
vA(t)=ddtxA(t)v^A(t)=\frac{d}{dt}x^A(t)vA(t)=dtd​xA(t)

children.value: is Alice’s speed as measured by Brice, in the train. That is, the velocity of Alice as measured by Igor is the sum of the velocity of the train relative to the ground and the velocity of Alice relative to the train, which makes sense. If we now determine Alice’s acceleration,

children.html: a′A(t)a'^A(t)a′A(t)

children.value: , as measured by Igor, we find:

children.html: a′A(t)=ddtv′A(t)=ddt(v′B+vA)=0+ddtvA(t)=aA\begin{align} a'^A(t)&=\frac{d}{dt}v'^A(t)\\ &=\frac{d}{dt}(v'^B+v^A)\\ &=0+\frac{d}{dt}v^A(t)\\ &=a^A \end{align}a′A(t)​=dtd​v′A(t)=dtd​(v′B+vA)=0+dtd​vA(t)=aA​​

children.value: where we have explicitly used the fact that the train is moving at constant velocity (

children.html: ddtv′B=0\frac{d}{dt}v'^B=0dtd​v′B=0

children.value: ). Here we find that both Brice and Igor will measure the same number when referring to Alice’s acceleration (if the train is moving at constant velocity). This is a particularity of “inertial” frame of references: accelerations do not depend on the reference frame, as long as the reference frames are moving with a constant velocity relative to each other. As we will see later, forces exerted on a object are directly related to the acceleration experienced by that object. Thus, the forces on a object do not depend on the choice of inertial reference frame.
